title: 110_s2815
content: The Act titled "Strengthening Student Aid for All Act" increases unsubsidized Stafford loan limits for undergraduate students. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 increase annual loan limits for undergraduate dependent students. The maximum amount they can borrow in an academic year is the sum of the previous limit plus $1,000. The maximum aggregate amount of loans for undergraduate independent students is $29,500. Annual limits for undergraduate independent students include the sum of the determined amount plus $1,000. The maximum aggregate amount of loans for undergraduate independent students is $29,500. For students attending an eligible institution who have not completed their first 2 years of undergraduate study, the additional amount they can receive is $6,000 if enrolled in a program of at least one academic year in length. The maximum additional amount a student can receive for undergraduate education is $7,000 if they have completed their first and second years but not the remainder of the program. The maximum annual loan amount for a student in an undergraduate program with less than one academic year remaining is determined based on the remaining time in semester, trimester, quarter, or clock hours. For students enrolled in specific coursework, the maximum amount is $6,000. The maximum aggregate amount of loans a student in an undergraduate program may borrow is $57,500. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 further specify loan limits for graduate students. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 specify loan limits for graduate students, including changes to loan amounts and eligibility criteria. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 specify loan limits for graduate students, including changes to loan amounts and eligibility criteria. In paragraph (3), the phrase "independent, graduate" is revised to just "graduate." Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include in-school deferment of PLUS loans for parents of dependent students until the student stops being enrolled at least half-time. Additionally, a secondary market of last resort is established under Part B of title IV. The Secretary serves as the secondary market of last resort for certain loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. They buy loans from eligible lenders at a price equal to the outstanding principal and accrued interest, hold and service the loans in the same manner as similar loans, and cannot alter the loan terms. The Secretary can buy a representative subset of loans from eligible lenders under certain sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965, with the authority expiring on July 1, 2009. Loan terms cannot be altered except as necessary to comply with specific requirements. The Secretary has the authority to extend the provision for student loans beyond July 1, 2009, if economic circumstances require it. Each extension cannot exceed 12 months. The effective date of this amendment is upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. NEGATIVE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION. Section 475 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended for dependent students, specifically addressing the assessment resulting under paragraph (2) and the lowest assessment of adjusted available income. Section 476 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended for independent students without dependents other than a spouse, focusing on the calculation of available income and adjustments based on specific criteria. Section 477 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended for independent students with dependents other than a spouse, addressing the assessment calculation and adjustments based on specific criteria. Section 477 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended for independent students with dependents other than a spouse, focusing on assessment calculation adjustments. This includes changes to assessment schedules and rates, as well as simplified needs tests. The College Cost Reduction and Access Act is amended to change the expected family contribution calculation. The effective date for this change is July 1, 2009. Additionally, adjustments are made to Federal Pell Grants under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The College Cost Reduction and Access Act of 1965 is amended to increase the amount for students with negative expected family contribution for Federal Pell Grants. Students with a negative expected family contribution will be eligible for a Pell Grant equal to the maximum amount specified in the last appropriation Act for the award year, plus the Pell Grant increase described in paragraph (9) for that year. The College Cost Reduction and Access Act of 1965 is amended to increase Pell Grants for students with negative expected family contributions. The grant amount will be the maximum specified in the last appropriation Act for the award year, plus an additional amount equal to the student's expected family contribution absolute value. If the Pell Grant exceeds the student's cost of attendance, it will be reduced accordingly. The College Cost Reduction and Access Act of 1965 is amended to increase Pell Grants for students with negative expected family contributions without altering existing requirements or imposing additional ones. SEC. 6. LENDER-OF-LAST-RESORT. Section 428(j) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for students attending designated institutions of higher education in the State. Students applying for loans under this subsection due to inability to obtain loans elsewhere are also addressed. Additionally, institutions of higher education designated for participation in the program under this subsection are specified. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for students attending designated institutions in the State. Institutions can request participation in the lender-of-last-resort program for students who are eligible for interest benefits. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for students attending designated institutions in the State. Institutions can request participation in the lender-of-last-resort program for eligible students. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall take effect on the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 7 amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize necessary appropriations for section 427(c)(7). The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the date of enactment. SEC. 8 states that the amendments will generally take effect on July 1, 2008.
